cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Scrub
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Aardvarks (Tubulidentata)
Family: Aardvarks (Orycteropodidae)
Genus: Orycteropus
Species: afer
Aardvarks are adaptable to different climates. They can live in damp rain forests or dry savannahs: anywhere they can find termites!
Aardvarks typically come out of their burrows at night, but sometimes they stay out in the morning to sun themselves and warm up.
Aardvarks usually eat termites with their sticky tongues, but sometimes they just press their mouths over holes and suck out the bugs!

When an aardvark is attacked (by a lion, hyena, or leopard), it finds a hole, or quickly digs one, and backs into it for protection. If it can’t dig a hole, it fights back with all four feet and its tail.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the aardvark in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Aardvark (Afrikaans for "earth pig") is the common name for a burrowing, ant-eating mammal. The aardvark is found throughout much of Africa, from the southern part of Egypt to the Cape of Good Hope. A primarily nocturnal animal, it lives in burrows and feeds on ants and termites, occasionally eating other insects, the fat mouse, and a species of wild ground cucumber.
The aardvark is up to 2.3 m (7.5 ft) long, including the fleshy, tapering tail, which it uses to throw earth backward when it burrows. It has an arched back, a tubular snout, and large, upright ears. The aardvark uses its specialized, chisel-shaped claws to break open the hard clay of termite nests; then it uses its sticky tongue to capture the insects in the nest. Unlike the animals known as anteaters, which are toothless, the aardvark has 20 cylindrical, rootless teeth that grow continually throughout its lifetime.
The female gives birth to one or occasionally two offspring, which can dig their own burrows at the age of six months. Although timid, the aardvark will fight when it cannot flee or burrow to safety; it defends itself with its powerful claws or by striking with its tail or shoulders.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Vulnerable
Temperate Forest
Northwest Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Primates (Primata)
Family: Old World Monkeys (Cercopithecidae)
Genus: Macaca
Species: sylvanus
Only two members of the primate family are found in Europe: Barbary apes and humans!
Barbary "apes" are not actually apes at all. Though commonly called apes, they are actually tail-less monkeys!
Barbary apes form communities of 10 to 30 members, which are led by the females.
Males help raise the young and spend a lot of time playing with them.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Barbary ape in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Barbary ape is a tail-less monkey whose body is about 61 cm (24 in) long and covered with greenish-brown hair. It is the only macaque native to regions outside Asia, and it is abundant in some parts of North Africa. In the wild, the Barbary ape lives in high cedars and oak forests of the Atlas mountains of Morocco and Algeria. The wild population is estimated at between 14,000 and 23,000.
The Barbary ape occurs in fossil records during the Pleistocene Epoch (2.5 million to 10,000 years ago) and is now the only monkey found in Europe. This European population was probably introduced, however, and is restricted to about 240 animals, found on Gibraltar; when the population exceeds this number, the additional animals are shipped to zoos.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Grassland
Africa

Class: Birds (Aves)
Order: Diurnal Raptors (Falconiformes)
Family: Sagittariidae
Genus: Sagittarius
Species: serpentarius
Secretary birds sometimes walk up to 20 miles a day on their long legs.
In South Africa, secretary birds are sometimes kept as pets because they kill snakes and rats.
Snakes are a favorite food of secretary birds. They grab the snakes with their toes and beat them on the ground, using their wings to protect themselves from bites.
Secretary birds mate for life and keep the same nest for years. Though they lead solitary lives much of the time, the other half of the pair is usually not far away.
Secretary birds are silent nearly all the time. The only sound they make is a croaking when displaying for a mate.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the secretary bird in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Secretary bird is the common name for a large bird of prey, found in Africa south of the Sahara. It is more than 1 m (3 ft) in length and has very long legs, a long tail, and a powerful, hooked beak. Many books derive the origin of the bird's name from a fanciful resemblance of its crest of long feathers to a group of quill pens placed behind the ear. But the name is actually a mispronunciation of the Arabic name for the species. The general color of the bird is bluish gray; the primaries, thighs, and tail markings are black. The bird feeds on small animals and on reptiles, particularly snakes, generally by stalking them. Secretary birds rarely fly. These solitary birds build large, strong nests of twigs in trees or bushes and lay two eggs in a clutch.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Tropical Rainforest
Central Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Tragelaphus
Species: eurycerus
Bongos are the largest and most colorful of all African antelope.
The bongo’s main predator is the leopard.

When bongos run through the forest, they hold their antlers against the backs of their necks so they don’t get caught in the vegetation. They do this so often that many bongos have bald patches where they’ve rubbed off their fur!

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the bongo in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The bongo is a chestnut-colored antelope that lives in the forests of central and western Africa. Like some other varieties of antelope, they develop distinctive white vertical stripes down their shoulders, like dripped pastry icing. Both males and females have spiraling horns.
Bongos live on a diet of roots, sweet potato, branch tips, and shoots. Sometimes they even eat dirt or burned wood to get salt or other minerals. Their tongue can wrap around food, making it easier for them to feed from plants that are high off the ground.
Bongos are the only forest antelope to form herds. They are private, shy animals that run if they are the least bit frightened. Because they take refuge in the forest, habitat destruction is one of the main threats to the species.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Wetlands
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Syncerus
Species: caffer
The African buffalo is an herbivorous grazing animal that primarily eats grasses.
Lions are the primary predator of African buffalo.
When a herd member is attacked by a predator, other African buffalo come to its defense.
The protective plate that joins the horns of male African buffalo is called a "boss."
African buffalo are sociable animals that travel in large herds.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the African buffalo in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The African buffalo (also known as cape buffalo) is a wild oxen native to Africa. Like domestic cattle and some other artiodactyl mammals, buffalo are cud-chewing and have cloven hooves and permanent horns, but they are much larger and more powerful than cattle.
The African buffalo, which inhabits most of southern and central Africa, is a large and imposing creature, frequently cited as the most dangerous of all African species of big game. It weighs 500 to 900 kg (1100 to 1980 pounds) and measures about 1.7 m (5.5 ft) at the shoulder. It is noted for horns that are massive at the base, forming a helmet over the forehead and reaching a length of about 1 m (3 ft).
African buffalo range from semiarid savannas to rain forests and from lowland swamps and reed beds to high mountain meadows. The buffalo has retreated in many places as a result of hunting, settlements, agriculture, and a virulent disease called rinderpest, but the population still includes well over a million animals.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Scrub
Africa and Asia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Cats (Felidae)
Genus: Caracal
Species: caracal
The caracal is the fastest cat of its size.
Caracals are very quick hunters. They sometimes catch low-flying birds in the air!
Though it’s sometimes called the "Persian lynx," the caracal is not actually related to the lynx family and is found as far from Persia (modern day Iran) as South Africa.
If a caracal kills an animal that it can’t eat all at once, it drags the carcass up into a tree so other animals don’t get it.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the caracal in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The caracal, also known as the Persian lynx, is a cat native to the savannas and dry, rocky hills of Africa and Asia. The caracal is 60 to 92 cm (2 to 3 ft) in head and body length, with a tail length of 23 to 31 cm (9 to 12 in). It is 38 to 50 cm (15 to 20 in) high at the shoulder, and weighs 13 to 19 kg (29 to 42 lb). It has a reddish-brown coat, white belly, and tufts of black hair on the tips of its ears (the name "caracal" means "black ears" in Turkish). Caracals prey on rodents, birds, and small antelope. In India and Iran, caracals are sometimes tamed and used for hunting because of their speed and agility. They also hunt nesting or roosting birds at the tops of trees and have been known to attack eagles. The caracal has been over hunted but is now a protected species.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Vulnerable
Alpine
Ethiopia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Primates (Primata)
Family: Old World Monkeys (Cercopithecidae)
Genus: Theropithecus
Species: gelada
While the gelada family unit is male-centric, it is not male-dominated. The females of the band are smaller than the males, but as a group, they are powerful, and they know it!
When predators are nearby, the male gelada emits a two-phase bark that sounds like "wahoo!"

Geladas have a complex social structure and need a lot of communication to maintain it. There are 27 different sounds in the gelada language, as well as tactile communication and numerous facial expressions.
Gelada families often have younger males that linger near the harem and eventually leave with some younger females to start new families.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the gelada in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The gelada is closely related to the baboon. It is distinguished from baboons, however, by the structure of its nostrils, which are farther from the tip of the mouth than those of the baboon. The adult male gelada has a very distinctive cape of hair that covers its head and hangs down its back.
The gelada is an African animal that lives in the mountain grasslands primarily in Ethiopia. It is found only at altitudes of between 1400 and 4400 meters above sea level. The gelada lives almost entirely on a diet of grass, mixed with a few roots, bulbs, and the occasional locusts and insects. Because of this restricted diet, it spends much of the day grazing.
The gelada social structure involves groups of many male-centered families. A male gelada has as many as a dozen females as simultaneous mates. These uni-male family units get together to form larger bands of several hundred that forage together, and those bands also group together for form even larger groups.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Scrub
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Litocranius
Species: walleri
The name gerenuk means "giraffe-necked" in the Somali language.
Gerenuks can eat plants that are six to eight feet from the ground.
Because gerenuks feed only on taller plants, they are able to live peacefully with animals that feed on the lower ones.
As part of the mating ritual, the male gerenuk approaches a female and repeatedly taps her on the belly with one of his front legs.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the gerenuk in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The gerenuk is a relative of the gazelle. It differs from gazelles in that it has an elongated neck and a more solid skull. Only the males have horns.
Gerenuks live in small groups. Some groups are made up of females and their young, and other groups are made up exclusively of males. The males tend to hold specific territories, while the female groups may wander, often through several of the male territories. There is no specific mating season for the gerenuk. Because they are adaptable eaters, they can mate at any time of the year.
Gerenuks are vegetarians and use their long necks to reach up for high-growing plants. They even stand on their hind legs to feed, using their forelegs to pull down the branches of trees. Gerenuks are prey for cheetahs, leopards, lions, and jackals.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Savannah
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Giraffes (Giraffidae)
Genus: Giraffa
Species: camelopardalis
Subspecies: tippelskirchi
The Masai giraffe is the tallest land animal.
It is also the largest ruminant, which is a hoofed animal that chews cud. (A cow is another type of ruminant.)
A mother giraffe stands over her calf and defends it from lions and hyenas with her sharp hooves.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Masai giraffe in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Masai giraffe is one of nine subspecies of the giraffe family. Giraffes have short, dense fur with an intricate pattern of dark patches that range from tannish-yellow to chestnut brown. This coloration helps giraffes blend in among trees and leaves, making them harder for predators to spot. Although no two giraffe skin patterns are exactly the same, some regional patterns are so common and distinct that zoologists have identified a number of giraffe subspecies based on the patterns. One of the most striking of these subspecies is the reticulated giraffe, which has large brown patches separated by thin contrasting lines, making a pattern that looks like broken paving. The Masai giraffe has patches with complex jagged outlines. In all giraffes, the coat color tends to become darker with age. In captivity, giraffes have lived into their mid-30s, but their maximum lifespan in the wild is about 25 years.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Critically Endangered
Tropical Rainforest
Central Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Hippopotamuses (Hippopotamidae)
Genus: Hexaprotodon
Species: liberiensis
Subspecies: heslopi
Most pygmy hippos in American zoos today are descended from one that was given to President Calvin Coolidge in 1927.
Pygmy hippos aren’t born knowing how to swim. They need to learn from their mothers.
Pygmy hippos excrete a white oil that protects their skin during the long periods they spend in the water.
Other than the large river (or Nile) hippo, the pygmy hippo’s closest relatives are pigs and peccaries.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the pygmy hippopotamus in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The most obvious difference between the pygmy hippopotamus and the more common river hippopotamus is size. Pygmy hippos stand only about two and half feet tall at the shoulder, and weigh 350 to 550 pounds. That may seem heavy to humans, but the larger river hippo can weigh up to 8,000 pounds.
We know much less about the habits of pygmy hippos than we do of their larger relatives. Not only are pygmy hippos rare, but they are also nocturnal and solitary (they only come together to mate), so it is difficult to observe them in the wild. Unlike river hippos, which are spread out over much of the African continent, pygmy hippos are only found in a small area in western Africa.
Like all hippos, pygmy hippos are herbivores. They graze on grasses, succulent plants, fallen fruit, and other low-lying vegetation.
In the wild, pygmy hippos have suffered from human activity. Both habitat loss and hunters have caused the population to dwindle. There is, however, a stable population in zoos.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Desert
North Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Hyenas (Hyaenidae)
Genus: Hyaena
Species: hyaena
The striped hyena has been known to chase away leopards and cheetahs from food sources, but it always lets the larger spotted hyena steal its food.
In some villages in Africa, people leave their garbage out at night for striped hyenas to feed on.
Striped hyenas rarely eat in a group because they want to avoid direct competition for food.
Although its diet consists mainly of carrion, the striped hyena has also been known to leap in the air to catch moths and other flying insects.
The striped hyena avoids deserts and requires a source of water (its range is within six miles of a water source).

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the striped hyena in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The hyena is a doglike carnivore that is a renowned scavenger. Hyenas have powerful jaws capable of crushing large bones that other predators cannot eat. The hyena's range spans Africa, the Middle East, and southwestern Asia, including India. In prehistoric times, hyenas also roamed Europe. Their habitat is usually open plains and grasslands, but they are sometimes found in rocky terrain, brush-covered areas, and open forests.
There are three species of hyenas: the spotted hyena, the striped hyena, and the brown hyena. Of these, the spotted hyena is the largest. The size of striped hyenas ranges in length from 1.2 to 1.5 m (3.9 to 4.9 ft), including the 30 cm (12 in) tail, and in weight from 25 to 55 kg (55 to 120 lb). Striped hyenas are yellow-brown with dark stripes and an upright mane on their necks and backs.
All hyenas share the characteristic of a distinctly sloping back, resulting from a size difference between their large, muscular front legs and smaller back legs. Each foot has four toes with nonretractable claws that help hyenas to run on the open plains. Hyenas have small heads that contain massive jaws and teeth. A prominent anal pouch, located under the base of the long, bushy tail, is used for scent marking.
Most active at night, hyenas typically scavenge the kills of other animals, feeding on the body parts left behind. They are able to bite through tough hides and crush and digest large bones. Indigestible materials, such as hair, hooves, and horns, are formed into pellets in the digestive tract and regurgitated through the mouth. Hyenas also make their own kills. Capable of running up to 65 km/h (40 mph), individual hyenas will attack sheep, goats, wildebeest, and other animals, and they will form packs of ten or more to bring down a zebra.
Hyenas usually associate in strongly territorial clans, which are centered around communal dens. A clan may consist of 10 or 12 females, 20 young, known as whelps, and a number of males on the fringes. Pair bonding is not evident, and the female, larger than the male, selects her mating partners. Females conceive throughout the year, giving birth to one to five whelps after a gestation period of 92 to 110 days.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Vulnerable
Tropical Rainforest
Central Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Primates (Primata)
Family: Old World Monkeys (Cercopithecidae)
Genus: Mandrillus
Species: sphinx
The male mandrill is the most colorful mammal in the world!
Mandrills can hold large amounts of food in the pouches of their cheeks. If they need all four limbs to run from a predator, they can stuff their food into these pouches and go!
Though it lives in the forest, the mandrill is a ground-based monkey. It only goes into the trees to flee from predators and to sleep.
The primary predator of the mandrill is the leopard.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the mandrill in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 4 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The mandrill is a terrestrial baboon of tropical West Africa. The mandrill's heavy muscular body has stout, strong limbs and is coated with soft fur that is olive brown above, gray below, and merges into a yellow beard on the chin and a crest on the head. The eye ridges are prominent, and the eyes are small, deeply sunk, and close together. Enormous canine teeth add to its fierce appearance. Along the muzzle in front of the eyes is an especially large development of bony ridges that are covered with longitudinally ribbed naked skin. Adult head-and-body length reaches up to 90 cm (3 ft), and the tail is little more than a stump. The females are less brilliantly colored than the males and are generally smaller and more slender.
The adult male mandrill is readily distinguished by unique, brightly colored facial skin. The muzzle ridges are an intense cobalt blue, flanked by black, and the midline of the nose is bright scarlet. The blue color results from the structure of the skin, while the red color is due to skin pigment. The small, pointed ears are bluish black, and the beard and cheeks are yellowish white. The skin on the buttocks and inside the legs is naked and scarlet in color, shading to lilac, blue, or black. A male reaches full size and color at approximately nine years.
Mandrills are endangered as a result of hunting and habitat loss.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Scrub
Southern Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Civets (Viverridae)
Genus: Suricata
Species: suricatta
Subspecies: suricata
Meerkats are social animals that live in groups and share both a common toilet and babysitting responsibilities.
A group of meerkats, which usually numbers between five and 30 members, is called a "mob."
Because meerkats are considered a snack-sized treat by many predators, one meerkat always stands guard while the others sleep or feed.
The meerkat's diet includes beetles, spiders, centipedes, crickets, and scorpions (meerkats are immune to their venom).
The meerkat uses its tail for balance and to communicate with other members of its mob.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the meerkat in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The meerkat, also called the suricate, is a small member of the mongoose family that inhabits the southern part of Africa. Meerkats are known for their upright posture and highly sociable behavior.
Meerkats typically live in dry, open areas and savannas. Their range extends from southwestern Angola to South Africa. These social animals live in colonies, usually in places with sandy soil where they can dig elaborate underground burrows.
Meerkats measure about 25 to 35 cm (10 to 14 in) in length, not including the tail. They are more slender than many mongooses. They have pointed snouts, silvery-brown fur, and irregular dark stripes on the rump. Their faces are white with dark markings on the ears and around the eyes. Unlike most mongooses, suricates have four rather than five toes on each paw.
Meerkats forage for food only during the day and eat mainly insects, particularly beetles, spiders, and millipedes. They sometimes feed on small vertebrates, eggs, and roots. Meerkats typically have two to four young, which are often born in the fall or early winter after a gestational period of about 11 weeks. Both females and males care for, groom, and guard their offspring.
Meerkats typically stand up straight on their hind legs or even their toes to sniff the wind and search for attacking vultures. They have excellent vision and are capable of making at least ten types of sounds, including an alarm bark.
Because meerkats can carry rabies, they have been hunted or gassed in their burrows in areas where they pose a threat to humans. This has not reduced their numbers significantly. In South Africa, these affectionate and easily tamed creatures are often kept as pets.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Wetlands
Africa

Class: Reptiles (Reptilia)
Order: Diapsid Reptiles (Squamata)
Family: Monitor Lizards (Varanidae)
Genus: Varanus
Species: niloticus
The Nile monitor is the largest lizard in Africa.
Nile monitors are related to Komodo dragons, which are the largest lizards in the world today.
Monitor lizards are related to the mosasaurs, huge marine reptiles that lived millions of years ago.
Despite their short legs, Nile monitors are fast runners.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Nile monitor in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
Nile monitors are among the largest lizards in the world today. They have an aggressive temperament and great physical power in their jaws, legs, and tail. They often use their tail as a slashing weapon against their prey and in combat with other monitors.
Nile monitors are carnivorous and tend to swallow their prey whole, the way snakes do. Their diet is varied: they’ll eat grasshoppers and beetles, as well as birds, fish, rodents, and even other lizards.
Also known as a "water monitor," these lizards tend to live by rivers and streams in sub-Saharan Africa. They can grow to be six feet long. While they primarily dwell on the ground near the water, they have been known to climb trees to eat eggs from bird nests.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Grassland
Africa and Asia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Mustelids (Mustelidae)
Genus: Mellivora
Species: capensis
The ratel has short legs but great endurance. It has been known to chase a larger animal for a long time, until the prey collapses from exhaustion.
Ratels sometimes chase young lions away from their kills and take the food!
Ratels have few animal predators. Their tough hide resists even snake bites!
The ears of the ratel are enclosed in their skin, so they can keep dirt out when digging holes.
Ratels sometimes emit smelly secretions to drive away predators. Ratels also use their scent to drive bees out of hives so they get at the honey!

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the ratel in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The ratel, also known as the honey badger, is a medium-sized, skunk-like mammal native to Africa and parts of Asia. Named for its habit of eating honey, the ratel is also a courageous fighter, willing to attack cobras, cattle, and even bison.
Ratels are found throughout most of Africa as well as in southern and central Asia, ranging eastward from the Arabian Peninsula to India and Nepal. They inhabit forests as well as open grasslands and dry savannas.
Ratels have muscular bodies, measuring between 60 and 77 cm (24 and 30 in) long, not including the 20 to 30 cm (8 to 12 in) tail. They may weigh up to 13 kg (29 lb). The ratel’s markings are quite distinctive. The head, neck, and back are covered with coarse, gray-white fur, while the face, legs, belly, and short furry tail are solid black. A small number of ratels are entirely black. Their short legs and large, strong claws are well adapted for digging.
Ratels are extremely difficult to kill. Their skin is unusually tough and is attached loosely to the body, making it hard for other animals to grasp. Animal bites, bee stings, or porcupine quills usually do not penetrate the ratel’s tough hide. As an added deterrent to predators, the anal glands of ratels can emit a foul-smelling liquid.
The ratel (or honey badger) is so named because bee honey is one of its favorite foods. In parts of Africa, the ratel finds beehives with the help of a bird that eats bee larvae, called the honey guide. When it finds a beehive, the bird gives a series of characteristic calls to guide the ratel to it. The ratel then uses its strong legs, claws, and teeth to tear open the hive, and both animals feed on the contents. Other foods in the ratel’s diet include insects, eggs, birds, lizards, snakes, plants, and small mammals. It forages for food in either the day or night.
Ratels live in underground burrows that they dig with their strong legs and claws. They den in groups but often hunt alone or in pairs. After mating, the female experiences delayed implantation, which means the fertilized eggs do not start developing for several months. The gestational period, including this delay, is thought to be about six months. The female gives birth to one to four young, which she raises in a grass-lined chamber.
Ratels are known to be quite courageous--they will attack large animals, such as horses, cattle, antelope, and buffalo, if these creatures intrude upon their burrows. Because of their fierce style of self-defense, ratels have not been widely hunted for their fur. In spite of this ferocity, they are sometimes raised as pets, because they can be tame and affectionate if caught young. An adult ratel is still a strong, energetic animal, however, and pets have been known to damage cages and other property and to attack without apparent reason.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Scrub
Southern Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Odd-Toed Ungulates (Perissodactyla)
Family: Rhinoceroses (Rhinocerotidae)
Genus: Ceratotherium
Species: simum
Subspecies: simum
The white rhinoceros is the world’s largest grazing animal.
The white rhino is not actually white. Its name comes from the Afrikaans word "weit," meaning "wide," and describing the shape of its mouth.
The white rhino has very poor eyesight and relies on its sense of smell. Its olfactory passages are actually larger than its brain!

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the white rhinoceros in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 2 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The white rhinoceros, also called the "square-lipped" rhino, is one of five species of rhinoceros alive today. Three of those species live in Asia, and the other two (the white rhino and the black rhino) live in Africa.
The white rhino is the largest of the rhino species and also the most peaceful. The black rhino is only about half the size of the white rhino but is much more aggressive. Both African rhinos have two horns on the end of their noses. The horns are not made of bone, as they are with cows and antelope; they are actually deposits of keratin fibers, which is the same protein that hair is made of.
All rhinos are vegetarians. Although the black rhino feeds on leaves and twigs, the white rhino lives almost entirely on grass. In fact, it eats so much grass that it is one of the few animals classified as a "megaherbivore."

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Vulnerable
Desert
North Africa

Class: Reptiles (Reptilia)
Order: Tortoises (Testudines)
Family: Tortoises (Testudinidae)
Genus: Geochelone
Species: sulcata
When it is excessively hot, the African spurred tortoise salivates over the front of its body to keep cool.

While African spurred tortoises need a high-fiber vegetarian diet, fruit is bad for them. In fact, most of the foods in the produce section of grocery stores are too sugary or too high in protein for their digestive systems.
The African spurred tortoise is the third-largest species of tortoise in the world. Only the Galapagos giant tortoise and Aldabra tortoise are larger.
Unlike some tortoises, African spurred tortoises don’t hibernate because the temperature in the Sahel desert, where they are from, never gets low enough for hibernation.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the African spurred tortoise in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The African spurred tortoise is the largest land tortoise on the African continent, weighing 105 kg (240 lb). These large animals require large amounts of space. They are also very strong and require sturdy exhibits when housed in zoos.
African spurred tortoises require a high-fiber diet to remain healthy. In the wild, they graze on mixed grasses, clover, and the pads of prickly pear cactus. They also need foods that are high in calcium, because they grow to be so large. They depend on succulent plants for their water supply.
These tortoises are very aggressive toward each other from the time they hatch. Males occasionally ram into each other and try to flip each other over.
When the weather gets too hot, African spurred tortoises burrow to avoid dehydration. If there is mud available on a hot day, they cover themselves in it as much as possible, even flipping it up onto their shells with their legs. To avoid the extreme temperatures of the day, they are most active at dusk and at dawn. They sometimes bask in the morning sunshine to warm up after a cold night.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Savannah
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Pigs (Suidae)
Genus: Phacochoerus
Species: africanus
Subspecies: aetheopicus
Warthogs sleep and rest in holes, but they prefer to take them over from other animals (especially aardvarks) rather than dig them.
When threatened, a warthog will snort or grunt, flatten its ears, and go underground with only its tusks exposed.
Warthogs groom themselves by taking sand baths, rubbing against trees and termite mounds, and letting birds pick insects off their bodies.
A determined grazer, the warthog kneels on its calloused, padded knees to reach the short grass it feeds upon.
The warthog's main predators are lions and leopards.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the warthog in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 3-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The warthog is a wild pig that has two pairs of tusks and two pairs of wart-like protuberances on a long, wide head. Warthogs have stocky bodies with thin legs, and a long, tufted tail. Widespread on the plains and open woodlands of Africa, their diet includes grass, berries, bark, roots, and carrion. They are normally diurnal, spending the night in burrows, but in places with heavy human activity warthogs may become nocturnal. One or two females with young form small groups, which a male may join briefly during mating season; young males form bachelor groups, but older males are solitary. Male offspring separate from their mother after a maximum of 15 months. Female offspring may stay in the mother's herd for their entire lives. Offspring, regardless of gender, are driven off when new offspring are born. The older offspring sometimes return to the mother later. The warthog's tusks are sharp weapons used against such predators as lions; fights with other warthogs are mostly pushing matches, the tusks seldom used.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Low Risk
Savannah
Africa

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Even-Toed Ungulates (Artiodactyla)
Family: Bovids (Bovidae)
Genus: Connochaetus
Species: taurinus
Wildebeests primarily eat grasses.
Lions and hyenas primarily eat wildebeests.
Wildebeests protect themselves by gathering in large herds.
Wildebeests are noisy; they often moan, bellow, and snort.
Wildebeest herds have been known to migrate up to 1,200 miles per year.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the wildebeest in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 1 1/2-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The wildebeest, also known as a gnu, is a large African antelope with an oxlike head, horns, and shoulders; bristly facial hair and mane; and a horselike tail. Two species exist: the black wildebeest, which was once abundant in South Africa but has now been hunted back to about 10,000 individuals; and the blue wildebeest, herds of which are common on grassy plains from Kenya south to northern South Africa. Both sexes of both species have broad, smooth horns that curve downward, outward, and then upward.
The blue wildebeest, which varies from bluish-gray to brown, is native to the open woodlands and grasslands of southern Africa and is one of its fastest residents. It weighs approximately 272 kilograms (600 lb) and stands about 137 cm (54 in) tall. Its large head and short neck support horns more than 61 cm (24 in) long, but its best defense is that it is a tireless runner. Although the bristly faces and massive shoulders make wildebeests appear menacing, they go into antics when approached, dashing off and wheeling about to gaze at intruders.
Wildebeests roam the African savanna in herds of 30 to 500. More than 1 million forage for grasses on the Serengeti Plain alone. Females bear single calves, which can run a few minutes after birth. Mothers in a herd synchronize reproduction, generating a flood of calves that overwhelms the appetites of predators. The young are frequently taken by hyenas, and the adults are a favorite prey of lions. Single males defend territories and court estrous females crossing their land. Males without territories form loose bachelor herds. In dry seasons some herds migrate in huge congregations.
Content adapted from Microsoft® Encarta® 2006. © 1993–2005 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

cell.color:
Conservation Status:
Critically Endangered
Alpine
Ethiopia

Class: Mammals (Mammalia)
Order: Carnivores (Carnivora)
Family: Canines (Canidae)
Genus: Canis
Species: simensis
The Ethiopian wolf is the only wolf found in Africa.
Though the Ethiopian wolf is typically active during the day, it occasionally becomes nocturnal when facing danger from nearby humans.
Only the dominant male and female in a pack breed, but the other wolves help to raise the young pups.
Ethiopian wolves use their strong-smelling urine to mark their territories.

LOC_STRING.cell:
To unlock the Ethiopian wolf in challenge or campaign games, you must earn a 5-star zoo fame rating for your zoo.
The Ethiopian wolf is distantly related to the jackal family and is sometimes referred to as the Simien jackal. It is the only type of wolf in Africa and is found in only a handful of mountain ranges in Ethiopia and Eritrea.
Ethiopian wolves are carnivores and generally feed on rodents, including the giant mole-rat. They hunt by digging rodents out of their burrows. Or sometimes they walk very slowly and quietly through areas where rodents are numerous and chase one down and snatch it off the ground. On rare occasions, Ethiopian wolves hunt cooperatively to bring down a larger animal, such as a young antelope or a lamb.
The Ethiopian wolf is critically endangered. There are only about 400 adult Ethiopian wolves left in the world. The species is officially protected by the Ethiopian government, and there is an organization at Oxford University in England to save this species.
